text: The Lord gave this message to Hosea son of Beeri during the years when Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were kings of Judah, and Jeroboam son of Jehoash was king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord first began speaking to Israel through Hosea, he said to him, “Go and marry a prostitute, so that some of her children will be conceived in prostitution. This will illustrate how Israel has acted like a prostitute by turning against the Lord and worshiping other gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hosea married Gomer, the daughter of Diblaim, and she became pregnant and gave Hosea a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “Name the child Jezreel, for I am about to punish King Jehu’s dynasty to avenge the murders he committed at Jezreel. In fact, I will bring an end to Israel’s independence.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will break its military power in the Jezreel Valley.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon Gomer became pregnant again and gave birth to a daughter. And the Lord said to Hosea, “Name your daughter Lo-ruhamah—‘Not loved’—for I will no longer show love to the people of Israel or forgive them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will show love to the people of Judah. I will free them from their enemies—not with weapons and armies or horses and charioteers, but by my power as the Lord their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Gomer had weaned Lo-ruhamah, she again became pregnant and gave birth to a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “Name him Lo-ammi—‘Not my people’—for Israel is not my people, and I am not their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet the time will come when Israel’s people will be like the sands of the seashore—too many to count! Then, at the place where they were told, ‘You are not my people,’ it will be said, ‘You are children of the living God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Judah and Israel will unite together. They will choose one leader for themselves, and they will return from exile together. What a day that will be—the day of Jezreel—when God will again plant his people in his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In that day you will call your brothers Ammi—‘My people.’ And you will call your sisters Ruhamah—‘The ones I love.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now bring charges against Israel—your mother—
    for she is no longer my wife,
    and I am no longer her husband.
Tell her to remove the prostitute’s makeup from her face
    and the clothing that exposes her breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, I will strip her as naked
    as she was on the day she was born.
I will leave her to die of thirst,
    as in a dry and barren wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will not love her children,
    for they were conceived in prostitution.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their mother is a shameless prostitute
    and became pregnant in a shameful way.
She said, ‘I’ll run after other lovers
    and sell myself to them for food and water,
for clothing of wool and linen,
    and for olive oil and drinks.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For this reason I will fence her in with thornbushes.
    I will block her path with a wall
    to make her lose her way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she runs after her lovers,
    she won’t be able to catch them.
She will search for them
    but not find them.
Then she will think,
‘I might as well return to my husband,
    for I was better off with him than I am now.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
She doesn’t realize it was I who gave her everything she has—
    the grain, the new wine, the olive oil;
I even gave her silver and gold.
    But she gave all my gifts to Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now I will take back the ripened grain and new wine
    I generously provided each harvest season.
I will take away the wool and linen clothing
    I gave her to cover her nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will strip her naked in public,
    while all her lovers look on.
No one will be able
    to rescue her from my hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will put an end to her annual festivals,
    her new moon celebrations, and her Sabbath days—
    all her appointed festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will destroy her grapevines and fig trees,
    things she claims her lovers gave her.
I will let them grow into tangled thickets,
    where only wild animals will eat the fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish her for all those times
    when she burned incense to her images of Baal,
when she put on her earrings and jewels
    and went out to look for her lovers
but forgot all about me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But then I will win her back once again.
    I will lead her into the desert
    and speak tenderly to her there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will return her vineyards to her
    and transform the Valley of Trouble into a gateway of hope.
She will give herself to me there,
    as she did long ago when she was young,
    when I freed her from her captivity in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When that day comes,” says the Lord,
    “you will call me ‘my husband’
    instead of ‘my master.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Israel, I will wipe the many names of Baal from your lips,
    and you will never mention them again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day I will make a covenant
    with all the wild animals and the birds of the sky
and the animals that scurry along the ground
    so they will not harm you.
I will remove all weapons of war from the land,
    all swords and bows,
so you can live unafraid
    in peace and safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make you my wife forever,
    showing you righteousness and justice,
    unfailing love and compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will be faithful to you and make you mine,
    and you will finally know me as the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In that day, I will answer,”
    says the Lord.
“I will answer the sky as it pleads for clouds.
    And the sky will answer the earth with rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the earth will answer the thirsty cries
    of the grain, the grapevines, and the olive trees.
And they in turn will answer,
    ‘Jezreel’—‘God plants!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time I will plant a crop of Israelites
    and raise them for myself.
I will show love
    to those I called ‘Not loved.’
And to those I called ‘Not my people,’
    I will say, ‘Now you are my people.’
And they will reply, ‘You are our God!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Go and love your wife again, even though she commits adultery with another lover. This will illustrate that the Lord still loves Israel, even though the people have turned to other gods and love to worship them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I bought her back for fifteen pieces of silver and five bushels of barley and a measure of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to her, “You must live in my house for many days and stop your prostitution. During this time, you will not have sexual relations with anyone, not even with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This shows that Israel will go a long time without a king or prince, and without sacrifices, sacred pillars, priests, or even idols!
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterward the people will return and devote themselves to the Lord their God and to David’s descendant, their king. In the last days, they will tremble in awe of the Lord and of his goodness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord, O people of Israel!
    The Lord has brought charges against you, saying:
“There is no faithfulness, no kindness,
    no knowledge of God in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You make vows and break them;
    you kill and steal and commit adultery.
There is violence everywhere—
    one murder after another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why your land is in mourning,
    and everyone is wasting away.
Even the wild animals, the birds of the sky,
    and the fish of the sea are disappearing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Don’t point your finger at someone else
    and try to pass the blame!
My complaint, you priests,
    is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So you will stumble in broad daylight,
    and your false prophets will fall with you in the night.
    And I will destroy Israel, your mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people are being destroyed
    because they don’t know me.
Since you priests refuse to know me,
    I refuse to recognize you as my priests.
Since you have forgotten the laws of your God,
    I will forget to bless your children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The more priests there are,
    the more they sin against me.
They have exchanged the glory of God
    for the shame of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When the people bring their sin offerings, the priests get fed.
    So the priests are glad when the people sin!
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘And what the priests do, the people also do.’
    So now I will punish both priests and people
    for their wicked deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will eat and still be hungry.
    They will play the prostitute and gain nothing from it,
for they have deserted the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text:
to worship other gods.
“Wine has robbed my people
    of their understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ask a piece of wood for advice!
    They think a stick can tell them the future!
Longing after idols
    has made them foolish.
They have played the prostitute,
    serving other gods and deserting their God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They offer sacrifices to idols on the mountaintops.
    They go up into the hills to burn incense
    in the pleasant shade of oaks, poplars, and terebinth trees.
“That is why your daughters turn to prostitution,
    and your daughters-in-law commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But why should I punish them
    for their prostitution and adultery?
For your men are doing the same thing,
    sinning with whores and shrine prostitutes.
O foolish people! You refuse to understand,
    so you will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though you, Israel, are a prostitute,
    may Judah not be guilty of such things.
Do not join the false worship at Gilgal or Beth-aven,
    and do not take oaths there in the Lord’s name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel is stubborn,
    like a stubborn heifer.
So should the Lord feed her
    like a lamb in a lush pasture?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave Israel alone,
    because she is married to idolatry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the rulers of Israel finish their drinking,
    off they go to find some prostitutes.
    They love shame more than honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So a mighty wind will sweep them away.
    Their sacrifices to idols will bring them shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear this, you priests.
    Pay attention, you leaders of Israel.
Listen, you members of the royal family.
    Judgment has been handed down against you.
For you have led the people into a snare
    by worshiping the idols at Mizpah and Tabor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have dug a deep pit to trap them at Acacia Grove.
    But I will settle with you for what you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know what you are like, O Ephraim.
    You cannot hide yourself from me, O Israel.
You have left me as a prostitute leaves her husband;
    you are utterly defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your deeds won’t let you return to your God.
    You are a prostitute through and through,
    and you do not know the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When they come with their flocks and herds
    to offer sacrifices to the Lord,
they will not find him,
    because he has withdrawn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have betrayed the honor of the Lord,
    bearing children that are not his.
Now their false religion will devour them
    along with their wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sound the alarm in Gibeah!
    Blow the trumpet in Ramah!
Raise the battle cry in Beth-aven!
    Lead on into battle, O warriors of Benjamin!
speaker: Narrator

text:
One thing is certain, Israel:
    On your day of punishment,
    you will become a heap of rubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The leaders of Judah have become like thieves.
    So I will pour my anger on them like a waterfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Israel will be crushed and broken by my judgment
    because they are determined to worship idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will destroy Israel as a moth consumes wool.
    I will make Judah as weak as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When Israel and Judah saw how sick they were,
    Israel turned to Assyria—
to the great king there—
    but he could neither help nor cure them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will be like a lion to Israel,
    like a strong young lion to Judah.
    I will tear them to pieces!
I will carry them off,
    and no one will be left to rescue them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will return to my place
    until they admit their guilt and turn to me.
For as soon as trouble comes,
    they will earnestly search for me.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In just a short time he will restore us,
    so that we may live in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that we might know the Lord!
    Let us press on to know him.
He will respond to us as surely as the arrival of dawn
    or the coming of rains in early spring.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Israel and Judah,
    what should I do with you?” asks the Lord.
“For your love vanishes like the morning mist
    and disappears like dew in the sunlight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I sent my prophets to cut you to pieces—
    to slaughter you with my words,
    with judgments as inescapable as light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want you to show love,
    not offer sacrifices.
I want you to know me
    more than I want burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But like Adam, you broke my covenant
    and betrayed my trust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Gilead is a city of sinners,
    tracked with footprints of blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Priests form bands of robbers,
    waiting in ambush for their victims.
They murder travelers along the road to Shechem
    and practice every kind of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, I have seen something horrible in Ephraim and Israel:
    My people are defiled by prostituting themselves with other gods!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Judah, a harvest of punishment is also waiting for you,
    though I wanted to restore the fortunes of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I want to heal Israel, but its sins are too great.
    Samaria is filled with liars.
Thieves are on the inside
    and bandits on the outside!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its people don’t realize
    that I am watching them.
Their sinful deeds are all around them,
    and I see them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The people entertain the king with their wickedness,
    and the princes laugh at their lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all adulterers,
    always aflame with lust.
They are like an oven that is kept hot
    while the baker is kneading the dough.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On royal holidays, the princes get drunk with wine,
    carousing with those who mock them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their hearts are like an oven
    blazing with intrigue.
Their plot smolders through the night,
    and in the morning it breaks out like a raging fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Burning like an oven,
    they consume their leaders.
They kill their kings one after another,
    and no one cries to me for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The people of Israel mingle with godless foreigners,
    making themselves as worthless as a half-baked cake!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Worshiping foreign gods has sapped their strength,
    but they don’t even know it.
Their hair is gray,
    but they don’t realize they’re old and weak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their arrogance testifies against them,
    yet they don’t return to the Lord their God
    or even try to find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The people of Israel have become like silly, witless doves,
    first calling to Egypt, then flying to Assyria for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as they fly about,
    I will throw my net over them
and bring them down like a bird from the sky.
    I will punish them for all the evil they do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What sorrow awaits those who have deserted me!
    Let them die, for they have rebelled against me.
I wanted to redeem them,
    but they have told lies about me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They do not cry out to me with sincere hearts.
    Instead, they sit on their couches and wail.
They cut themselves, begging foreign gods for grain and new wine,
    and they turn away from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I trained them and made them strong,
    yet now they plot evil against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They look everywhere except to the Most High.
    They are as useless as a crooked bow.
Their leaders will be killed by their enemies
    because of their insolence toward me.
Then the people of Egypt
    will laugh at them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sound the alarm!
    The enemy descends like an eagle on the people of the Lord,
for they have broken my covenant
    and revolted against my law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Israel pleads with me,
    ‘Help us, for you are our God!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is too late.
The people of Israel have rejected what is good,
    and now their enemies will chase after them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people have appointed kings without my consent,
    and princes without my approval.
By making idols for themselves from their silver and gold,
    they have brought about their own destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Samaria, I reject this calf—
    this idol you have made.
My fury burns against you.
    How long will you be incapable of innocence?
speaker: Narrator

text:
This calf you worship, O Israel,
    was crafted by your own hands!
It is not God!
    Therefore, it must be smashed to bits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They have planted the wind
    and will harvest the whirlwind.
The stalks of grain wither
    and produce nothing to eat.
And even if there is any grain,
    foreigners will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Israel have been swallowed up;
    they lie among the nations like an old discarded pot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a wild donkey looking for a mate,
    they have gone up to Assyria.
The people of Israel have sold themselves—
    sold themselves to many lovers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But though they have sold themselves to many allies,
    I will now gather them together for judgment.
Then they will writhe
    under the burden of the great king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Israel has built many altars to take away sin,
    but these very altars became places for sinning!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even though I gave them all my laws,
    they act as if those laws don’t apply to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people love to offer sacrifices to me,
    feasting on the meat,
    but I do not accept their sacrifices.
I will hold my people accountable for their sins,
    and I will punish them.
    They will return to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel has forgotten its Maker and built great palaces,
    and Judah has fortified its cities.
Therefore, I will send down fire on their cities
    and will burn up their fortresses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O people of Israel,
    do not rejoice as other nations do.
For you have been unfaithful to your God,
    hiring yourselves out like prostitutes,
    worshiping other gods on every threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now your harvests will be too small to feed you.
    There will be no grapes for making new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You may no longer stay here in the Lord’s land.
    Instead, you will return to Egypt,
and in Assyria you will eat food
    that is ceremonially unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There you will make no offerings of wine to the Lord.
    None of your sacrifices there will please him.
They will be unclean, like food touched by a person in mourning.
    All who present such sacrifices will be defiled.
They may eat this food themselves,
    but they may not offer it to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What then will you do on festival days?
    How will you observe the Lord’s festivals?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if you escape destruction from Assyria,
    Egypt will conquer you, and Memphis will bury you.
Nettles will take over your treasures of silver;
    thistles will invade your ruined homes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The time of Israel’s punishment has come;
    the day of payment is here.
    Soon Israel will know this all too well.
Because of your great sin and hostility,
    you say, “The prophets are crazy
    and the inspired men are fools!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The prophet is a watchman over Israel for my God,
    yet traps are laid for him wherever he goes.
    He faces hostility even in the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The things my people do are as depraved
    as what they did in Gibeah long ago.
God will not forget.
    He will surely punish them for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says, “O Israel, when I first found you,
    it was like finding fresh grapes in the desert.
When I saw your ancestors,
    it was like seeing the first ripe figs of the season.
But then they deserted me for Baal-peor,
    giving themselves to that shameful idol.
Soon they became vile,
    as vile as the god they worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of Israel will fly away like a bird,
    for your children will not be born
or grow in the womb
    or even be conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if you do have children who grow up,
    I will take them from you.
It will be a terrible day when I turn away
    and leave you alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have watched Israel become as beautiful as Tyre.
    But now Israel will bring out her children for slaughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, what should I request for your people?
    I will ask for wombs that don’t give birth
    and breasts that give no milk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says, “All their wickedness began at Gilgal;
    there I began to hate them.
I will drive them from my land
    because of their evil actions.
I will love them no more
    because all their leaders are rebels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Israel are struck down.
    Their roots are dried up,
    and they will bear no more fruit.
And if they give birth,
    I will slaughter their beloved children.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My God will reject the people of Israel
    because they will not listen or obey.
They will be wanderers,
    homeless among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How prosperous Israel is—
    a luxuriant vine loaded with fruit.
But the richer the people get,
    the more pagan altars they build.
The more bountiful their harvests,
    the more beautiful their sacred pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hearts of the people are fickle;
    they are guilty and must be punished.
The Lord will break down their altars
    and smash their sacred pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will say, “We have no king
    because we didn’t fear the Lord.
But even if we had a king,
    what could he do for us anyway?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spout empty words
    and make covenants they don’t intend to keep.
So injustice springs up among them
    like poisonous weeds in a farmer’s field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Samaria tremble in fear
    for their calf idol at Beth-aven,
    and they mourn for it.
Though its priests rejoice over it,
    its glory will be stripped away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This idol will be carted away to Assyria,
    a gift to the great king there.
Ephraim will be ridiculed and Israel will be shamed,
    because its people have trusted in this idol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samaria and its king will be cut off;
    they will float away like driftwood on an ocean wave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the pagan shrines of Aven, the place of Israel’s sin, will crumble.
    Thorns and thistles will grow up around their altars.
They will beg the mountains, “Bury us!”
    and plead with the hills, “Fall on us!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says, “O Israel, ever since Gibeah,
    there has been only sin and more sin!
You have made no progress whatsoever.
    Was it not right that the wicked men of Gibeah were attacked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now whenever it fits my plan,
    I will attack you, too.
I will call out the armies of the nations
    to punish you for your multiplied sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Israel is like a trained heifer treading out the grain—
    an easy job she loves.
    But I will put a heavy yoke on her tender neck.
I will force Judah to pull the plow
    and Israel to break up the hard ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Plant the good seeds of righteousness,
    and you will harvest a crop of love.
Plow up the hard ground of your hearts,
    for now is the time to seek the Lord,
that he may come
    and shower righteousness upon you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you have cultivated wickedness
    and harvested a thriving crop of sins.
You have eaten the fruit of lies—
    trusting in your military might,
believing that great armies
    could make your nation safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the terrors of war
    will rise among your people.
All your fortifications will fall,
    just as when Shalman destroyed Beth-arbel.
Even mothers and children
    were dashed to death there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will share that fate, Bethel,
    because of your great wickedness.
When the day of judgment dawns,
    the king of Israel will be completely destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When Israel was a child, I loved him,
    and I called my son out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the more I called to him,
    the farther he moved from me,
offering sacrifices to the images of Baal
    and burning incense to idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I myself taught Israel how to walk,
    leading him along by the hand.
But he doesn’t know or even care
    that it was I who took care of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I led Israel along
    with my ropes of kindness and love.
I lifted the yoke from his neck,
    and I myself stooped to feed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But since my people refuse to return to me,
    they will return to Egypt
    and will be forced to serve Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
War will swirl through their cities;
    their enemies will crash through their gates.
They will destroy them,
    trapping them in their own evil plans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my people are determined to desert me.
They call me the Most High,
    but they don’t truly honor me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, how can I give you up, Israel?
    How can I let you go?
How can I destroy you like Admah
    or demolish you like Zeboiim?
My heart is torn within me,
    and my compassion overflows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, I will not unleash my fierce anger.
    I will not completely destroy Israel,
for I am God and not a mere mortal.
    I am the Holy One living among you,
    and I will not come to destroy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For someday the people will follow me.
    I, the Lord, will roar like a lion.
And when I roar,
    my people will return trembling from the west.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a flock of birds, they will come from Egypt.
    Trembling like doves, they will return from Assyria.
And I will bring them home again,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel surrounds me with lies and deceit,
    but Judah still obeys God
    and is faithful to the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Now the Lord is bringing charges against Judah.
    He is about to punish Jacob for all his deceitful ways,
    and pay him back for all he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even in the womb,
    Jacob struggled with his brother;
when he became a man,
    he even fought with God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he wrestled with the angel and won.
    He wept and pleaded for a blessing from him.
There at Bethel he met God face to face,
    and God spoke to him—
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies,
    the Lord is his name!
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now, come back to your God.
    Act with love and justice,
    and always depend on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no, the people are like crafty merchants
    selling from dishonest scales—
    they love to cheat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel boasts, “I am rich!
    I’ve made a fortune all by myself!
No one has caught me cheating!
    My record is spotless!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But I am the Lord your God,
    who rescued you from slavery in Egypt.
And I will make you live in tents again,
    as you do each year at the Festival of Shelters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I sent my prophets to warn you
    with many visions and parables.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the people of Gilead are worthless
    because of their idol worship.
And in Gilgal, too, they sacrifice bulls;
    their altars are lined up like the heaps of stone
    along the edges of a plowed field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob fled to the land of Aram,
    and there he earned a wife by tending sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then by a prophet
    the Lord brought Jacob’s descendants out of Egypt;
and by that prophet
    they were protected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the people of Israel
    have bitterly provoked the Lord,
so their Lord will now sentence them to death
    in payment for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the tribe of Ephraim spoke,
    the people shook with fear,
    for that tribe was important in Israel.
But the people of Ephraim sinned by worshiping Baal
    and thus sealed their destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now they continue to sin by making silver idols,
    images shaped skillfully with human hands.
“Sacrifice to these,” they cry,
    “and kiss the calf idols!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, they will disappear like the morning mist,
    like dew in the morning sun,
like chaff blown by the wind,
    like smoke from a chimney.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have been the Lord your God
    ever since I brought you out of Egypt.
You must acknowledge no God but me,
    for there is no other savior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I took care of you in the wilderness,
    in that dry and thirsty land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when you had eaten and were satisfied,
    you became proud and forgot me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now I will attack you like a lion,
    like a leopard that lurks along the road.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bear whose cubs have been taken away,
    I will tear out your heart.
I will devour you like a hungry lioness
    and mangle you like a wild animal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are about to be destroyed, O Israel—
    yes, by me, your only helper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now where is your king?
    Let him save you!
Where are all the leaders of the land,
    the king and the officials you demanded of me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my anger I gave you kings,
    and in my fury I took them away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Ephraim’s guilt has been collected,
    and his sin has been stored up for punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pain has come to the people
    like the pain of childbirth,
but they are like a child
    who resists being born.
The moment of birth has arrived,
    but they stay in the womb!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should I ransom them from the grave?
    Should I redeem them from death?
O death, bring on your terrors!
    O grave, bring on your plagues!
    For I will not take pity on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim was the most fruitful of all his brothers,
    but the east wind—a blast from the Lord—
    will arise in the desert.
All their flowing springs will run dry,
    and all their wells will disappear.
Every precious thing they own
    will be plundered and carried away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Samaria
    must bear the consequences of their guilt
    because they rebelled against their God.
They will be killed by an invading army,
    their little ones dashed to death against the ground,
    their pregnant women ripped open by swords.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God,
    for your sins have brought you down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bring your confessions, and return to the Lord.
    Say to him,
“Forgive all our sins and graciously receive us,
    so that we may offer you our praises.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Assyria cannot save us,
    nor can our warhorses.
Never again will we say to the idols we have made,
    ‘You are our gods.’
No, in you alone
    do the orphans find mercy.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says,
“Then I will heal you of your faithlessness;
    my love will know no bounds,
    for my anger will be gone forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will be to Israel
    like a refreshing dew from heaven.
Israel will blossom like the lily;
    it will send roots deep into the soil
    like the cedars in Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its branches will spread out like beautiful olive trees,
    as fragrant as the cedars of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people will again live under my shade.
    They will flourish like grain and blossom like grapevines.
    They will be as fragrant as the wines of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Israel, stay away from idols!
    I am the one who answers your prayers and cares for you.
I am like a tree that is always green;
    all your fruit comes from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those who are wise understand these things.
    Let those with discernment listen carefully.
The paths of the Lord are true and right,
    and righteous people live by walking in them.
    But in those paths sinners stumble and fall.
speaker: Narrator
